text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The United Nations under secretary-general Kieran Prendergast is due in Cyprus on Wednesday to assist the proximity talks conducted between the Greek and Turkish Cypriot sides in preparation of direct talks.
- A Turkish vessel has docked in Kyrenia, searching for oil reserves in the sea between Cyprus and Turkey.
- Man tried to strangle his mentally-retarded son because he thought he was illegitimate.
- Ethics probe starts into dealings of Cyprus Ports Authority (CPA). Parliamentarians accuse some CPA officials of nepotism.
- A concert by Greek and Turkish singers Sakis Rouvas and Burak Kut will go ahead next Monday in spite of opposition by some groups.
- Parliamentarians hear claims of nepotism and bribery in the Cyprus Ports Authority.
- The government says an invitation by the United Nations secretary-general for direct talks with the Turkish Cypriot side will be difficult to refuse.
- We will say "yes" if we are invited to talks. Mediators spur their involvement.
- Police are to table new regulations to parliament banning use of portable phones or eating and drinking while driving.
- Nicosia will pre-empt an invitation to talks with the Turkish Cypriot side by the secretary-general, stating that it will agree to them.
